intro: Astragalus saratagius subsp. artschamajdani, commonly known as the Siberian milkvetch, is a perennial legume native to the steppes and mountainous regions of Central Asia. It features a robust taproot system and typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm. The plant has compound leaves with small, oval leaflets and produces yellow to orange flowers in umbellate clusters. It is well adapted to dry, sandy soils and is often found in open habitats. This subspecies is valued for its ecological role in soil stabilization and as a forage plant for livestock.
